1E652F5FB37C4FC183061A7C10EB0D11.description: Begins to understand consequences of own actions when prompted by the teacher (e.g., “Tell me what is a good reward for helping your friends clean up their block game.”).

6F25F930AE694C3A874ED8639AF71876.description: Increased ability to understand verbal explanations of phenomena that are not directly experienced, as long as the child has had similar experiences (e.g., “The sun gives off heat. Even though you can’t see it, it’s happening.”).

CFBC56DEA393426596CA4B25AD1C2D75.description: Demonstrates understanding of the world around her/him.

143DA684C5674CF79043E2E67ADF08ED.description: Begins adhering to social norms in pretend play (e.g., only girls can be mommies).

DB045986A44C48E28ED2717D2B0FAEF0.description: Imitates and sustains pretend play independently and negotiates the roles.

86656CB8E075458CA1BFD4FB2E788B68.description: Engages in pretend play and acts out roles

531F4DFF99E94E1DB33C07425C15A887.description: Landscapes are composed carefully, giving the impression that removing any single form would throw off the balance of the whole picture.

D23C978C293E457E8D4A19B3ECC7A54D.description: Develops a set of symbols to create a landscape that eventually becomes a single variation repeated endlessly.

E05660AFC430434BA1BFAF812B205053.description: Represents people, places, or things through drawings, movement, and three-dimensional objects.

F5AF47CAFBA34F6B99DA5D8E7067A1D3.description: Continues to benefit from hands-on experiences to support more abstract thinking skills (e.g., makes a book about last summer's vacation trip, complete with sections for each place visited, drawings to illustrate, and labels written with adult help).

87482C930B8D4545982E59A0E3F8859A.description: Begins to understand and appropriately care for items that belong to someone else.

820415F3C211419D8A11E1F2A0FA833C.description: Demonstrates appropriate use of classroom materials with consistency and independently.

A0B1B102566B4925BEF86A4307D703A4.description: Cleans up after activities, placing items in their appropriate place independently.

038BDBA1DBA74D6991426357E933D143.description: Demonstrates appropriate use of materials or belongings and those of others.

D707CD774F664A739E8DBE599369AB91.description: Engages in out-of-classroom activities and successfully re-enters the classroom routine without disruption independently.

A3DFFAD6EF08454D8FFBFB99495624E3.description: Consistently transitions easily from home to school.

4AA1491DA2F74F43A33C9D0E08F0DD71.description: Arrives at school ready to engage in the classroom routine.

3FA7BE392F1B4F75A670E69B977545ED.description: Demonstrates the ability to adapt to new environments with appropriate behaviors independently.

B5A6A0D852324B1D8BD2B3590FCF89F5.description: Responds to visual or auditory prompts and cues to transition to the next activity with little or no adult prompting.

284C29B8D78A488AACBDC4450E97DBA3.description: Consistently demonstrates the ability to independently stop an engaging activity to transition to another less desirable activity.

2DDCFF4C97784BB9B673CABCCF6F3A0B.description: Demonstrates the ability to stop one activity and start another

20FBC30088AA48F3BB00C745A57204CC.description: Behaves appropriately within the context of school routines (i.e., exiting the bus or attending school assemblies).

091C446F49B549F6BB6DE3890F554114.description: Identifies classroom routines by day of the week (i.e., understanding on Monday music is after lunch, etc.).

06D45C3549024F0AB7F52F407B9E95DB.description: Able to plan their activities around the classroom routine.

ED5EB2DFBD4B4046A71805EC31C5BD12.description: Able to help problem-solve rules in support of fair treatment of everyone.

56B3BC4098D546F38DD972A601B33BF6.description: Able to recognize rules as fair or unfair.

68F0C072FE704035AC9E805D1D49D058.description: Able to help create school rules.

8AD8173F11834235A417CA43F11C5A83.description: Able to answer why specific rules exist (i.e., safety rules).

AD979583BFB047DB8F10E4FD16F8A286.description: Understanding and complying with classroom rules, routines and expectations

E5159D12E2754015BE8591D115226E17.description: Uses more complex language to express his or her understanding of feelings and their causes (e.g., says, "I want to try riding on that, but I'm sort of scared, too.").

1CC37127B0B643B4A23F94A14B4C694E.description: Uses a broader repertoire of strategies, including negotiation and compromise, to resolve conflicts before seeking adult help (e.g., says, "I have a great idea, Henry! You be the bear, and I will be the lion. Then we can switch!").

3275B3C86C8D42ABB2ED7F2DC0D340B0.description: Continues to establish and maintain friendships with other children. Seeks others' acceptance and friendship (e.g., says, "We're buddies, right?").

4AFF3197DFED49DC9BAE53462923996D.description: Uses a wider array of words or actions to demonstrate awareness, understanding, and concern for what others are feeling (e.g., goes over to a child whose block building has fallen down and says, "Don't worry, Manuel. I'll help you build it up again.").

26A3ADF1ED26499DA566703E1E10B792.description: Will consistently try a new approach to a problem when the old one is not working (e.g., immediately rotating a puzzle piece to find a better fit).

55705FA2C3D5484B85E687C9A4D4EC4C.description: Experiences difficulty with writing, however, continues to try writing letters and numbers independently until the task is completed.

E9AF3813F78A495ABB0402FA90ADD3DD.description: Continues to attempt to build a tower even after three or more unsuccessful attempts independently.

1D1C158DE8634BBF90CFC0EF0F6E9FF5.description: Can persist in completing a complicated plan (e.g., creating a parade in the classroom that involves making instruments, costumes, and decorations).

9331A7AFE4004DB58D975DB0F53CB405.description: Keeps working to complete a task even if it is moderately difficult (e.g., persists with a somewhat challenging wooden puzzle).

A6BEEA9A7D23475CABAFE1AFDE345BDC.description: Persists with a wider variety of tasks, activities, and experiences with adult prompting.

941568E7669846599DDD42B5F16288D6.description: Persists in an activity from start to finish (completeatask) -independently

821D7152CF7445CD942AF8FB20758D20.description: Independently takes initiative to solve problems occurring within activities without immediately requiring adult support (e.g., the child will search for the missing piece in the doctor’s kit for several minutes before asking for help).

C35AEEB22352438DB17AC5BB0EFC4161.description: Actively participates in creating games or activities with peers.

B90EB9A147BE44988F301D1567EE00AE.description: Self-selects a variety of activities during free choice and puts away related materials where they belong when finished prior to transitioning to the next activity.

86403072682C4F52BEE93A140166C1E1.description: Independently plans a project and gathers materials needed to execute the project.

425D758995A04125B6C9B4BECD2D8BA1.description: Independence in learning – plans and initiates projects

CAF63F129A4B4AF1814ED298B14BC8B3.description: Shows interest and skill in more complex self-help skills (e.g., zips jacket, prepares a snack).

2747C1891372465BB2EE2A2B36E1AC48.description: Attempts activities that are new and challenging. May deliberately take risks when learning new skills.

05ECD8B85DF74616B64E6D918AA8AA3E.description: Desire to learn – interest in challenges

C983F852C8544E419631290635B6DB9D.description: Expands verbal and nonverbal enthusiasm for learning new things, including academic (i.e., reading, writing) and physical skills (i.e., riding a bike).

1006F5C0734C4DFE9D1198F7E844EA9F.description: Tries an even wider range of new experiences, both independently and with peers and adults.

2C8153C026DE4387B514E5F4A1807C90.description: Poses questions to seek explanations on a variety of topics.

03C26B6CA7924E6ABF106E362C43A805.description: Asks higher-level questions (e.g., "What would happen if we had no food?" or "Why was Raymond mad at me?").

8385118EB3294BF6A46042119BD2CAA7.description: Desire to learn – asks questions and seeks new information

F92C0C4C984E48758F8562E0693BE3C4.description:
May slow down and use self-talk to
think about what to do when
approaching problem.

618922934A6E40A098009E5BBB832B9E.description: Able to negotiate conflicts with other children independently by considering a few potential solutions.

AC8771F16328402886C652D9FDC41EF1.description: Utilizes varied and flexible approaches to solve longer-term or more abstract challenges (e.g., when planning to have friends over on a rainy day, thinks about how to deal with a limited space to play).

E4EA9E375AFF4C1D8F689AC80C01B942.description: Becomes increasingly able to think creatively about multiple solutions to a problem (i.e., analyzes possible results).

14E5CD10872C47A3B3F79ACD490D5A04.description: Solves problems by planning and carrying out a sequence of actions; may seek more than one solution and explain their reasoning (i.e., discusses the number of people who want some playdough, suggests methods for dividing it, and how they might determine if the pieces are all the same).

9B561A696B264E6AB1E7394486356471.description: Flexible problem solving-seeks multiple solutions to a question, task, or problem.

1CE2504B25BB425980D558984CE3AC80.description: Can sort by different attributes independently.

AA719A8C2BB34057B8E17CE994A417EB.description: Able to recognize and correct mistakes.

FB03C5682C6449F18D5D3FE83910325F.description: Can consistently follow different rules in different contexts and quickly learn and follow new rules in new contexts.

2633AAC3A2774DF8BFEF75289BF75D3F.description: Becomes skilled at games like Simon Says that require the child to follow two different rules and can shift rules without direct prompting.

553BC4B0FAFE4B51A97EEA0443D04C77.description: Can change roles easily during the play if necessary or desired.

E69941E5B33F4FF5A28857EAE2F72E7B.description: Sustains roles in pretend play independently and negotiates the roles.

3AE5B4B5885449D9B451F84B746381D2.description: Can flexibly apply rules to games and behavior

B8EF77622C8C4F23937445CB831E0A1C.description: Can enjoy success at complex memory games, including games requiring the tracking of hidden objects (e.g., a memory game on a rotating board).

5142B75D36284ECCBE94D3FB8B44DF64.description: Can keep track of the parts for more complicated projects involving many pieces.

D5195C87862A4B3EBB4227D2FC2C9415.description: Can contribute appropriately to more complex group discussions, holding in mind both the topic of discussion and the contributions of peers.

BC8D67A17710422C89CE946C7CDBB093.description: Identifies and can hold in mind school rules independently.

0708F6B3564A4BE192F2DDF6BBF30664.description: Spends time deliberating and weighing choices (e.g., may spend a long time thinking about whether to go to the store with mom or to stay home and help dad).

8C40760DC8F24C8F92CD40E08581C06F.description: Remembers several key points in a story and then answers questions accurately (e.g., how did the main character feel when she finds the dog?).

B9624A33769747E0974B82FB1572036D.description: Demonstrate the ability to hold and manipulate information

E923714CB5364E2E81CA80019AFE02FB.description: Uses self-talk and other strategies to maintain focus on difficult tasks and assignments from adults (e.g., “There’s only 3 more questions left. If I finish these, then I’ll be all done with this project.”).

F0EE8FA5648644BCAD1C08A8F51F97DB.description: Can independently pause and resume an activity to respond to an interruption.

278191013D3F4BCA8B25EABA4000B980.description: Independently avoids distractions and remains on task for short periods of time during a teacher-directed activity.

ACF72BA25E8C44E3AB956C2EB9D96D8B.description: Attentiveness – Resists distraction to maintain focus on tasks set by someone else

9AA65C79D2DA4E08B68A33C46E27C823.description: Able to independently maintain focus on a project of interest for a sustained period of time (e.g., spends a rainy day building a complicated fort out of chairs and blankets, complete with props and signs).

07CC85505CFE46F8A36D82763A550BF4.description: Capable of resisting distractions and keeping attention focused on a task of interest to the child.

BAFF5596716E41A294FC2C177957762B.description: Attentiveness – Resists distraction to maintain focus on tasks of interest to the child

E6D15DA136484E719DE3AC0668DBC5F1.description: Controls the expression of emotion; however, he or she continues to need adult guidance in this area.

97410852B56C475FA35BD0DB2A9C9903.description: Uses physical, imaginative, and cognitive resources to comfort self (e.g., goes to his or her desk or designated quiet area voluntarily when upset) and resists impulse to harm self, others, or property.

FADD516E37804F77969D8C28E62AACCF.description: Can consistently wait for a highly desired food or object when asked. May decide independently to wait as well (e.g., decides to eat a favorite food last).

A3166D63D278438FB95D0E9ED4BC3229.description: Able to take turns with preferred toys or classroom materials.

CBC41048A12E45708772C7BF494A26C3.description: Consistently waits for an object without grabbing.

065EE6130B054065AA3B9826A1C23B0F.description: More skillful at games like Red Light, Green Light that require waiting for a signal to do something.

1EAAE1282F794D61882C1C5A1E10BEB3.description: More able to monitor behaviors and resist habits when they are not appropriate.

70FAA593A9874CCA98F96EA8A1532A42.description: Enjoys working collaboratively to develop complex rules for games (particularly dramatic play) and provide reminders of these rules when necessary.

65F92DBFD98C4A46AD496A03F39929C4.description: Can consistently control impulses during structured activities that are familiar (e.g., raising hand to talk).

C612B60D42BC4A0C8D8DA377D8AEBEB1.description: Avoids imitating the negative behaviors of peers.

4873BA87AA5D4B4C8B49C457D4DF1A42.description: Accepts conflict resolution strategies as suggested by others.

5360D60E00F841D2AAEBC475270708C0.description: Negotiates with others to solve problems.

A3E34023062A403DBF203FA1DBC789BB.description: Identifies interpersonal conflicts and considers verbal or nonverbal solutions to the conflict.

8CD57200BAAF46928D38BAD943CEF8B6.description: Begins to see the point of view of others (i.e., theory of mind).

BB9AD9CCAE2B4D1F9236C38615C1D457.description: Understands and accepts when a peer is not given the same instructions or structure (e.g., Alexander needs a fidget toy to help him stay calm when he’s upset).

89F276790EFF4E84BFB3CD1A26E3BEDB.description: Recognizes and accepts differences or similarities between self as compared to others (i.e., children with a disability, cultural differences, gender, etc.).

985B476513154898BDF4D93FB8721D59.description: Recognizes differences or similarities between self as compared to others

D657B98337994CC2A9A9B55B6C8513DA.description: Communicates to others about his friendships (e.g., tells a parent at pick-up about a new friend).

1433D913C812496185BB2AA25A3BA816.description: Asks permission to use others’ materials and accepts peers' responses.

A6522690DDFD43E98DDA53F50117B8A2.description: Plays or works with others cooperatively

A906A0A323674E3A850810AFCEEA120F.description: Determines when adult assistance is needed.

FE77A08F6744442B9AA08D00A59A68A0.description: Provides comfort and support for peers who are upset.

1E243157330E4BCCA86458B42527252B.description: Communicates negative emotions in an appropriate way and proposes a solution (e.g., says, “No” or “Stop” and proposes a solution to their problem—“Please give me back the book.”).

28460D62616142399B83AE2ABD1F17FB.description: Identifies feelings and expresses them to others (i.e., lets another child know they are happy, sad, mad, etc.) and is able to explain why (e.g., “I’m mad because you took my toy.”).

63F1CB97774244C8A5B5DED1ED9B9C5F.description: Expresses, understands, and responds to feelings(emotions) of others

9B81DFCC0CC6481FAF3AAF1D65F333FC.description: Independently takes initiative to solve problems occurring within activities without immediately requiring adult support (e.g., the child will search for the missing piece in a game for several minutes before asking for help).

EF1ECA82497148FD896EA09ABE9D1D13.description: Actively participates in creating games or activities with peers.

48F657643EFD42798CAFD67DE5C73604.description: Creates and/or participates in a new challenge independently.

6164B4D815D445D1A5D95F2D7266535B.description: Self-selects a variety of activities during free choice and puts away related materials where they belong when finished, prior to transitioning to the next activity.

F745148E324B4B6DB0EDD5250F1B95F5.description: Transitions between tasks and routines with a verbal and/or visual warning (i.e., requires limited to no additional prompts).

77893179F0C74D2ABA4263C59E56E935.description: Demonstrates independence in a range of routines and tasks
